utterance: Bethany Mcgregor-USDA: ARS: I was just going to bring up one more surveillance technique that I I've been seeing a little bit more of out there. Um I didn't want to make this whole conversation about vectors so I've tried to hold back on the uh the vector side of things just a little bit. But one thing that people are using a little bit more is called um Xeno surveillance. So you know, insects, especially biting insects tend to approach animals and they don't typically care too much if your animal is sick or not. In fact, a sick animal is an easier host to bite on, right? So you have insects that are going out and blood feeding and landing on and interacting with animals in the field all the time.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces Xeno surveillance as a new surveillance technique.

utterance: Bethany Mcgregor-USDA: ARS: Yeah, so all mosquitoes have a typical range that they'll disperse within. And I mean there are exceptions. utterance: Bethany Mcgregor-USDA: ARS: Um well yeah, if you're going to collect blood fed mosquitoes, you're going to want to use some kind of a resting trap because after you've had a big meal, you want to take a nap and so do the mosquitoes.
